greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Array: row n shows the square partitions of n.
comment: Suppose that p is a partition of n.  Let m X m be the size of its Ferrers matrix, f(p), defined at A237981.  Then f(p) consists of ceiling(m/2) concentric squares, where the innermost square is a single point if m is odd.  The square partition of p is introduced here as the partition [x(1), x(2) ,..., x(k)], where x(i) is the number of 1s in the i-th concentric square, where the squares are taken in order starting with the outermost.
link: Clark Kimberling, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
Clark Kimberling and Peter J. C. Moses, Ferrers Matrices and Related Partitions of Integers
example: The 7 square partitions of 12 are as follows:  [12], [11,1], [10,2], [9,3], [8,4], [8,3,1], [7,4,1].  The Ferrers matrix of the partition [4,3,3,1,1] of 12 is shown here:
The outermost square has 8 1s, the next has 3 1s, and the innermost, 1 1, so that [8,3,1] is a square partition of 12.  The first 9 rows of the array:
results.author: _Clark Kimberling_ and _Peter J. C. Moses_, Feb 25 2014
